subject: Re: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: ...  ... So you have two main test suites. 1. Object-level tests. 2. Integration tests. This necessarily means that you do not have the benefit of one
messageBody:
>So said Adam Jack on 2003-07-25 --------------------
<snip />
>I write unit tests for the low level objects, and also for the higher level
>aggregating objects that use them. This helps me track down the cause of
>high level failures much easier. When junit detects problems and things
>fail
>I get a (sometimes long) list of failures. Finding the "root cause" problem
>means sifting through all the failures (including the aggregating failures)
>in order to find the problem, perhaps down in a low level class test.

So you have two main test suites.

1. Object-level tests.
2. Integration tests.

This necessarily means that you do not have the benefit of "one defect, one failure", since likely you always have "one defect, at least two failures".

>Since
>I can't control the order of execution (it is likely package alphabetical
>or
>something), I can't tell what is the lowest level test. I'd like to reduce
>the effort invested here.

This is a myth. You *can* control the order of execution of test and of test suites; you simply have to maintain suites.

>I was wondering if jUnit could introduce the concept of "optional test
>dependencies", test X depends upon Y -- i.e. test Y runs before test X, and
>test X runs IFF test Y succeeds.

This is not something for JUnit to introduce, because it is already supported. Create a TestSuite from the specific tests you want to execute, and in the given order.

If you also want the behavior of "stop the presses if any test fails", then simply wrap the test methods you want to call in one big test method called "myLongTest" and run that one test method.

>I wouldn't want to do this for every test, and it ought be user optional,
>but I could see it as being a big benefit.

You can maintain a list of tests and run them as necessary. Simple.

>P.S. The Eclipse junit plugin that search projects to find all tests, find
>tests in dependant project, but doesn't run them "in the CWD of that
>project" (which matters for some tests).

It shouldn't. It is best to write your tests so that it doesn't. Or your production code; whichever. Pass the desired working directory into the tests as a JVM parameter or something.

Take care.
